questions.question: What type of tool is Claude Code?

answers.b: A CLI-based, agentic tool designed for engineering
answers.c: A mobile app for code review

questions.explanation: Claude Code is a CLI-based, agentic tool designed for engineering, empowering developers to automate tasks efficiently.

questions.question: What are the four steps of the Agentic Loop?
questions.explanation: The Agentic Loop consists of: Plan (analyze request), Execute (perform action), Verify (run tests/linters), and Iterate (fix errors and restart).

questions.question: Which Claude model is called the 'Senior Architect'?
questions.explanation: Opus 4.6 is called the 'Senior Architect' - the most intelligent model for building agents and coding.

questions.question: Which keyboard shortcut cancels the current action in Claude Code?
questions.explanation: ctrl+c cancels the current action. ctrl+d exits Claude, esc+esc rewinds the conversation, and shift+tab toggles between modes.

questions.question: What does CLAUDE.md serve as in a project?

answers.b: The context guide and configuration for Claude Code
answers.d: A markdown template for README files

questions.explanation: CLAUDE.md is the first file Claude reads when starting. It acts as the context guide and configuration, containing the project map, commands, coding standards, and boundaries.

questions.question: What are hooks in Claude Code?

answers.c: Automations that run at specific lifecycle events

questions.explanation: Hooks are automations that run at specific lifecycle events. Claude Code has 14 lifecycle events, with the most useful being PostToolUse, PreToolUse, Notification, Stop, and SessionStart.

questions.question: What is MCP in Claude Code?

answers.b: Model Context Protocol - an open standard connecting Claude to external tools
answers.d: Memory Compression Protocol for context management

questions.explanation: MCP stands for Model Context Protocol - an open standard that connects Claude to external tools, databases, and services, bridging AI to real-world systems.

questions.question: How many tools power the Claude Code agentic loop?
questions.explanation: Claude Code has 13 tools that power the agentic loop, split into tools that need permission (Bash, Write, Edit, etc.) and those that don't (Read, Glob, Grep, etc.).

questions.question: Which tool requires NO permission in Claude Code?
questions.explanation: Glob (find files by pattern), along with Read, Grep, Task, TodoWrite, and AskUserQuestion, requires no special permission. Bash, Write, Edit, WebFetch, WebSearch, Skill, and NotebookEdit require permission.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Plan Mode in Claude Code?

answers.a: To automatically deploy code to production
answers.b: To scout the territory, ask questions, and create a step-by-step plan before writing code
answers.c: To plan sprint tasks in a project management view

questions.explanation: Plan Mode lets Claude scout the territory, ask questions for better understanding, and create a step-by-step plan. You review and approve the plan before switching to edit mode.

questions.question: What are Agent Skills in Claude Code?

answers.a: Physical keyboard shortcuts assigned to agents
answers.b: Specialized knowledge that Claude discovers automatically for consistency and composability
answers.c: A list of programming languages an agent can code in

questions.explanation: Agent Skills are specialized knowledge that Claude discovers automatically. They ensure consistency, support composability (multiple skills at once), and are token-efficient (only paid when used).

questions.question: What is the purpose of Rules files in the .claude/rules/ directory?

answers.a: They define the allowed Git operations for the project
answers.b: They are specialized sub-manuals that deep-dive into specific technical domains, extending CLAUDE.md
answers.c: They store user preferences and UI settings
answers.d: They contain automated test rules for CI/CD pipelines

questions.explanation: Rules files in .claude/rules/ are the specialized sub-manuals of CLAUDE.md. Claude scans the folder and pulls the relevant rule file it needs for its mission, allowing deep-dives into specific technical domains.

questions.question: What does the settings.json file control in Claude Code?

answers.c: Security policy with hard boundaries: allow, deny, and ask permissions, plus hooks and extensions
answers.d: API key management for third-party services

questions.explanation: settings.json is the security policy defining hard boundaries: allow (pre-approved actions), deny (blocked operations), and ask (require confirmation), plus hooks for automation and extensions for plugins.

questions.question: What does 'context engineering' prioritize over 'prompt engineering'?

answers.a: Writing longer and more detailed prompts
answers.b: Treating context as a finite resource, minimizing tokens to prevent 'context rot'
answers.c: Using more powerful models for every request

questions.explanation: Context engineering treats context as a finite resource and minimizes tokens to prevent 'context rot' and maintain high reasoning precision, using just-in-time retrieval, hybrid management, and smart compaction.

questions.question: What is a key characteristic of Sub Agents in Claude Code?

answers.a: They share the same context as the main agent
answers.b: They can only run sequentially, one at a time
answers.c: They operate in isolation with their own context and can run in parallel
answers.d: They always use the most expensive model available

questions.explanation: Sub Agents are specialized workers that operate in isolation with their own context (leading to enhanced performance), utilize limited tools, can run in parallel, and each has its own model for resource efficiency.
